Well when we yawn our eyes moisten. And since our eyes get lubricated with tears when we blink during the day and we don't blink during sleep, we need another way to keep eyes from drying up.
When eyes are shut it is IMOEBIAN GLANDS above the eyeball and along eyelids that release secretions (oils) to lubricate eyes during sleep.
This explains why we always yawn before seep or on waking up and why we get crusty eyes in the morning.
All those other theories don't make a great deal of sense but the oil is essential to keep eyes moist when we can't blink.
Also , all the PHARMACEUTICAL preparations we PAY for just DILUTE the IMOEBIAN OIL and don't help DRY EYE AT ALL.

''* Answers claiming that yawning is cooling the brain are incorrect according to basic physics. The increased amount of heat carried by water evaporation in lungs during yawning is insignificant compare to a minute of regular breathing. Over a minute one yawn causes maybe 25% of extra ventilation. In general it can't meaningfully affect brain temperature:
Lets assume a human exhales an extra 3L of air during yawning (less in reality). It carries no more than 0.1g of water vapor (usually 2-3 times less). 0.1g of water vapor carries about 55 metric calories. The brain weighs around 1.5kg. If all 55 calories are somehow instantly transferred from the brain (and not spread over blood, lungs, other tissue), they can cool it off by only 0.03C.
Evaporating 1g of water as perspiration (breaking sweat) would carry 10 times more heat.''
(Quora answer - https://www.quora.com/Is-yawning-contagious-If-so-why-Whats-the-evidence)

I have a theory to why we yawn at different temperatures. I see this is the shower and outside sometimes. My idea: we yawn in specific temperatures as these temperatures may be the ones that we sleep with most often as we find it more comfortable. Or possibly because we either find these temperatures soothing in general, be it hot or cold. However I must say that I find warmth to be soothing but I must sleep in a semi-cold environment. In the shower I often set the water temperature to being as hot as possible, to which I begin to feel drowsy and begin to yawn. Even now I must say that I am yawning. Why do I say this? Because I'm standing outside, sun is up, and the air feels quite vibrant...soothing I must say, a temperature are what I would say as to being the one I sleep with. And the wind, usually I keep a fan on so I stay cool as I sleep, it is replicating the conditions that I fall asleep at. So in my theory, I believe this is because of sleeping condition replication.

According to one evolutionary theory, yawning is a survival mechanism- cooling and improving our brains functions in situations of stress/tiredness. This is important for social animals in the wild because one of the herd must remain alert for predators at all times. And if that individual becomes tired it triggers the yawn reflex in both itself and its surrounding herd- thus hopefully improving awareness and reducing the probability of being caught by a predator. This eplains why the reflex is contagious.

A new study has suggested that the reason we yawn has nothing to do with tiredness or boredom, but actually works in order to cool down our brains and help us think a little clearer.
Previously it’s been thought that yawning served a respiratory function, helping to wake us up with a jolt of oxygen when we were feeling sluggish, but studies have shown that yawning doesn’t actually increase oxygen levels in the body; something that tallies with the simple observation that we don’t yawn when we exercise, a time when we definitely need more oxygen.

So why do we yawn when we’re tired? Well, both sleep deprivation and exhaustion are known to increase brain temperature, so while it’s true that we yawn to combat lack of sleep, yawns don't make us ‘more awake’ but instead help keep our brains operating at the right temperature.
Why do we yawn? Nothing to do with boredom - we're just cooling our brains, say scientists

I lasted through the whole video, but I did use three "tricks" to do it -

1, I definitely took over my diaphragm (autonomous breathing instead of spontaneous breathing). That was necessary both to resist the urge to yawn and also for the next bits.

2. About once every 30 seconds, I hyperventilated for a few seconds. That's just to get the lungs thinking they're nicely saturated, whether they are or not.

3. Used a trick that air force pilots or astronauts employ to prevent blacking out at high G forces - total lower body clench to move oxygenated blood to the upper body. This was especially important after hyperventilating to prevent any risk of loss of consciousness.

A new research has been conducted on contagious yawning and how it is not linked to empathy. There are two types of yawning: spontaneous yawning, which occurs when someone is bored or tired, and contagious yawning, which occurs when a person hears, sees or thinks about yawning. Contagious yawning was recently found to be linked with age. As a person ages, their likelihood to contagiously yawn decreases, and past research suggested that it may by linked to variables like empathy, tiredness and energy levels but that is NOT TRUE. Research was conducted on 328 healthy volunteers that were prompted to watch a yawning video to see how many times they would yawn. The numbers ranged from zero to 15, and the numbers were consistent for each person for every round they did it. This means it had to be linked to genetics, and they found that people with disorders like autism or schizophrenia, both of which involve impaired social skills, demonstrate less contagious yawning despite still yawning spontaneously. So researchers suggested that people that do not yawn contagiously often, may have a trait from one of these disorders, but may not necessarily have the disorder. It is still not evident what is the factor for contagious yawning, but age is a factor.

Are you kidding me, what a load of bunk. Yawning is a variation of our breathing. A build up carbon dioxide is what causes to breathe, not a lack of oxygen. As we become inactive and are breathing slows carbon dioxide levels rise. If these levels
rise too much and we get behind in our intake of oxygen our body makes us yawn
to expel the excess carbon dioxide and replace it with fresh oxygen. Sighing
is a smaller form of this same process.

The link attached will take you to a petition. Unless this petition reaches 100,000signatures by next week, this will happen:
All websites containing media that refers to or is owned by a company that hasn’t given its permission for the media to be displayed can and will be shut down. This means sites such as Tumblr, Wattpad, Pinterist, fanfiction.com.
People who post such media can and will be fined, with a maximum sentence of five years in prison. This includes, but is not limited to, people who own/post the following: fanfiction, fan art, roleplay blogs, fan blogs/accounts and movie streaming sites.
"The legislation would allow copyright holders and the Justice Department to seek court orders against websites associated with copyright infringement. SOPA, the House version, applies to both domestic and foreign websites, while PIPA targets foreign websites. If that court order is granted, the entire website would be taken down. Internet users who typed in the site’s URL address would receive an error message, and for all appearances, the site would never have existed. Importantly, the court does not need to hear a defense from the actual website before issuing its ruling. The entire website can be condemned without a trial or even a traditional court hearing."meh
